title: Sarcomere Shortening of Pluripotent Stem Cell-Derived Cardiomyocytes using Fluorescent-Tagged Sarcomere Proteins.
procedures:
1. Differentiation of mouse pluripotent stem cells
Maintenance of mouse ES cells
	
Maintenance medium: Mix 50 mL of fetal bovine serum (FBS), 5 mL of L-alanine-L-glutamine, 5 mL of non-essential amino acid (NEAA), 5 mL of 100 mM Sodium Pyruvate, and 909 μl of 55 mM 2-Mercaptoethanol with 450 mL of Glasgow Minimum Essential Medium (GMEM). Supplement Leukemia inhibitory factor (LIF), CHIR-99021, and PD0325901 at a final concentration of 1000 U/mL, 1 μM, and 3 μM, respectively. Sterilize the medium through a 0.22 μm filter.
FBS medium: Mix 55 mL of FBS, 5.5 mL of L-alanine-L-glutamine, 5.5 mL of Sodium Pyruvate, and 5.5 mL of NEAA to 500 mL of Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM) high glucose. Filtrate the medium through a 0.22 μm filter to sterilize.
Culture SMM18 mouse ES cells in which TagRFP was knocked into the Myom2 locus on a gelatinized 6 cm dish in maintenance medium as previously described18. Passage every 2-3 days.
Preparation of serum-free differentiation (SFD) medium
	
Basal SFD: Mix 250 mL of Ham's F-12, 750 mL of Iscove's Modified Dulbecco's Medium (IMDM), 10 mL of B27 supplement minus Vitamin A, 5 mL of N2 supplement, 10 mL of L-alanine-L-glutamine, 5 mL of 10% bovine serum albumin in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and 10 mL of penicillin and streptomycin (10,000 U/mL). Filter through 0.22 μm strainer to sterilize.
Dissolve ascorbic acid at 5 mg/mL in distilled water and filter through 0.22 μm strainer to sterilize.
Dilute 13 µL of 1-Thioglycerol to 1 mL of IMDM. Herein, refer to this diluted 1-Thioglycerol as MTG.
Add 10 µL of ascorbic acid (5 mg/mL) and 3 µL of MTG to 1 mL of basal SFD on the day of use. Herein, refer to this mixture as complete SFD.
Day 0, embryoid body (EB) formation for differentiation

Harvest SMM18 mouse ES cells with a recombinant trypsin-like protease (rTrypsin) and count the cells.
Centrifuge 5 x 105 cells at 300 x g for 3 min in 4 °C, resuspend in 10 mL of complete SFD, and seed into a 10-cm Petri dish. Culture the cells at 37 °C and 5% CO2 for 50 h.
Differentiation day 2
	
Add Activin A, human vascular endothelial growth factor (hVEGF), and bone morphogenetic protein 4 (BMP4) to complete SFD at a final concentration of 5 ng/mL, 5 ng/mL, and 1.9 ng/mL, respectively.
		​NOTE: BMP4 concentrations may differ depending on the lot of BMP4. Test several concentrations in a small-scale trial prior to using a new lot and determine the best concentration for cardiac differentiation.
Transfer EBs from a Petri dish into a 15 mL tube and centrifuge at 50-100 x g for 3 min at 4 °C.
Meanwhile, add the medium prepared in step 1.4.1 to the Petri dish to protect the remaining EBs being dry.
Aspirate the supernatant from the 15 mL tube, resuspend the EBs with the medium in the Petri dish, and transfer the EB solution back to the dish. Then, cultivate the EBs at 37 °C and 5% CO2 for 46 h.
Differentiation day 4
	
Gelatinize a 10 cm tissue culture-treated dish with 5 to 10 mL of 0.1% gelatin for at least 5 min. Aspirate gelatin right before seeding cells.
Prepare medium: Mix basic fibroblast growth factor (bFGF), FGF10, and hVEGF to complete SFD at 5 ng/mL, 25 ng/mL, and 5 ng/mL final concentrations, respectively. For a 10 cm dish, prepare 10 mL.

Transfer cells from the Petri dish to a 15-mL tube. Add 5 mL of PBS to the Petri dish, wash several times, and transfer to the 15-mL tube to collect the remaining cells. Centrifuge at 50-100 x g, 4 °C, 3 min.
Aspirate supernatant, add 1 mL of rTrypsin, and incubate at 37 °C for 3 min.
Vortex briefly to dissociate EBs, add 9 mL of 10% FBS medium, vortex again, and count the cells.
Centrifuge 1.5 x 107 cells at 300 x g, 4 °C for 3 min, resuspend with the media prepared in step 1.4.2, and seed into the gelatinized dish. Incubate at 37 °C and 5% CO2 for 2 days.
		NOTE: By day 7 or 8, extensive beating of PSC-CMs can be observed.
Drug selection at differentiation days 7 and 9: Refeed the media with puromycin (2 μg/mL at the final concentration) to eliminate non-cardiomyocytes at day 7 and 9 of differentiation.
	​NOTE: Parental line of SMM18 is syNP4 mouse ES cells, harboring NCX1 promoter-driven puromycin-resistant gene20.
Day 10, replate for future experiments
	
Coat a glass-bottom culture plate or a 35 mm imaging dish containing a polymer coverslip with 0.1% Gelatin. To enhance maturation, coat the dishes with laminin-511 E8 fragment (LN511-E8) at 1 μg/cm2 for 30-60 min at room temperature18. To culture PSC-CMs in specific patterns of interest, please refer to steps 4 and 5 for preparing polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) stamps.
To harvest SMM18 PSC-CMs, wash the dish twice with PBS, apply 1 mL of rTrypsin, and incubate 3 min at 37 °C.
Collect cells in 9 mL of 10% FBS medium, suspend, and count the cells. Plate the cells at 50,000-100,000 cells in one well of a 24-well plate or 250,000-500,000 cells in a 35 mm imaging dish.

Centrifuge a sufficient number of cells (300 x g, 3 min) and resuspend the cells with complete SFD supplemented with FBS (final concentration at 10%).
Incubate overnight and change the culture medium to complete SFD with puromycin.
From day 14, change the culture medium two to three times a week with complete SFD until day 21-28, when Myom2-RFP becomes prominent. For AAV-based transduction of fluorescent-tagged sarcomere proteins, please refer to Step 3.
2. Differentiation of human pluripotent stem cells
Preparation of differentiation media
	
RPMI+B27-Ins: mix 500 mL of RPMI 1640 medium, 10 mL of B27 minus insulin, and 5.25 mL of L-alanine-L-glutamine.
RPMI+B27+Ins: mix 500 mL of RPMI, 10 mL of B27 supplement, and 5.25 mL of L-alanine-L-glutamine.
Maintenance of human iPS cells
	
Passage human iPS cells twice a week with AK02N on LN511-E8 following previously published method with some modifications21.
Harvest cells with a 3 min treatment of rTrypsin and collect into 10% FBS medium. Count cells and centrifuge at 300 x g for 3 min at 4 °C. Seed 75,000-125,000 cells in one well of 6 well plate with 2 mL of AK02N supplemented with LN511-E8 and Y27632 at the final concentration of 0.5 μg/mL (0.1 µg/cm2) and 10 μM, respectively.
Incubate at 37 °C and 5% CO2 and replace the medium the following day with 2 mL of AK02N without any supplement. Change media every two to three days and passage every three to four days.
Day -4: replate prior to differentiation
	
Coat a 6 well plate with 0.5 μg/cm2 of LN511-E8 diluted in PBS. Then, incubate for at least 30 min at 37 °C and 5% CO2 or 1 h at room temperature. Aspirate coating solution right before seeding cells.
Harvest human iPS cells with rTrypsin and count cells as in Step 2.2.2.

Centrifuge 1.25 x 105 cells for a well of a 6-well plate at 300 x g for 3 min at 4 °C and resuspend in 2 mL of AK02N supplemented with LN511-E8 (final concentration 0.5 μg/mL or 0.1 μg/cm2) and Y27632 (final concentration 10 μM) per well.
Aspirate coating solution, seed resuspended cells into the coated plate, and incubate at 37 °C and 5% CO2.
Days -3 and -1: replace medium with 2 mL of AK02N.
Day 0: Replace medium with 2 mL of RPMI+B27-Ins supplemented with CHIR99021 (final concentration 6 μM) per well to start differentiation.
Day 2: Replace medium with 2 mL of RPMI+B27-Ins with WntC59 (final concentration 2 μM) per well.
Day 4: Replace medium with 2 mL of RPMI+B27-Ins per well.
Day 7 and day 9: replace medium with 2 mL of RPMI+B27+Ins with puromycin (final concentration 10 μg/mL) per well to selectively culture PSC-CMs.
	​NOTE: ACTN2-mCherry line, used in this study, has a cassette of internal ribosomal entry site (IRES), puromycin-resistant gene inserted to the 3′-untranslated region (UTR) of TNNT2 locus, and mCherry replacing the stop codon of ACTN2. To purify cardiomyocyte without knock-in, please refer to Steps 3 and 4.
Day 10: replate for future experiments
	
Coat a 35 mm imaging dish with a polymer coverslip with 0.5-1 μg/cm2 of LN511-E8 diluted in 0.1% Gelatin. Incubate 2-4 h at room temperature for long-term viability. To culture PSC-CMs in desired patterns, please refer to steps 4 and 5 for preparing PDMS stamps.
To harvest human PSC-CMs, wash the dish twice with PBS, apply 1 mL of rTrypsin per well, and incubate 3 min at 37 °C.
Collect cells in 4 mL of 10% FBS medium, suspend, and count the cells. Plate 250,000-500,000 cells per 35 mm imaging dish.

Centrifuge a sufficient number of cells at 300 x g for 3 min at 4 °C, resuspend with RPMI+B27+Ins with puromycin (10 μg/mL), and plate on the coated 35 mm imaging dish.
Incubate overnight. The next morning, replace the culture medium with RPMI+B27+Ins with puromycin (10 μg/mL).
From day 14, change culture medium 2-3 times a week with RPMI+B27+Ins until day 21-28 for imaging. For AAV-based transduction of fluorescent-tagged sarcomere proteins, please refer to Step 3.
3. Fluorescent labeling of sarcomeres using adeno-associated viruses
Preparation before AAV production
	
Maintain HEK293T cells in DMEM supplemented with FBS (final concentration 10%) on a 10 cm tissue culture plate. Passage cells three times a week.
Prepare polyethylenimine (PEI) at 1 mg/mL. Mix 50 mg of polyethylenimine MAX 40000 and 40 mL of ultrapure water. Adjust pH to 7.0 using 1 N NaOH. Then, make the final volume to 50 mL with ultrapure water and filter through a 0.22 μm strainer.
Prepare a shuttle vector with a sarcomere labeling gene (e.g., TCAP or PDLIM3 fused with a green fluorescent protein [GFP]), driven by a cardiomyocyte-specific promoter, such as cardiac troponin T (cTNT)22.
		​NOTE: For this instance, we used monomeric enhanced GFP with mutations of V163A, S202T, L221V23.
Day 0, passage HEK cells
	
When cells reach confluency, passage 2.0 x 107 HEK293T cells to a 15 cm tissue culture plate with 20 mL of DMEM with 10% FBS.
Day 1, transfection
	
Mix 13.5 μg of the shuttle vector, 26 μg of pHelper (a vector coding E2A, E4, and VA of adenovirus), 16.5 μg of pRC6 (a vector coding AAV2 Rep and AAV6 Cap genes), and 1 mL of DMEM without sodium pyruvate (DMEM-Pyr).
Mix 224 μL of PEI (1 mg/mL, prepared in step 3.1.2) and 776 μL of DMEM-Pyr.

Mix and incubate the plasmid solution and the PEI solution at room temperature for 30 min.
Add the plasmid/PEI solution to the HEK293T cells prepared in step 3.2.
Day 2, medium change
	
At 24 h after transfection, change medium to DMEM-Pyr. Culture cells until harvesting AAV on day 7. AAV will be released into the culture media.
Day 7, AAV collection, concentration, and buffer substitution using minimal purification method24
Incubate a centrifugal ultrafiltration unit (100k molecular weight cut-off [MWCO]) with 5 mL of 1% BSA in PBS at room temperature for 15 min. Then, centrifuge the ultrafiltration unit at 500 x g for 2 min and aspirate both filtered and remaining solutions.
Transfer medium from the 15 cm dish that produced AAV to a new 50mL conical tube and centrifuge (500 x g, 5 min). Filter the supernatant through a 0.45 μm syringe strainer to remove cell debris and apply suspension to the ultrafiltration unit.
Centrifuge at 2000 x g for 90 min or until concentrating the culture supernatant 0.5 to 1 mL.
Aspirate the filtrate and apply 15 mL of PBS to the ultrafiltration unit.
Repeat centrifugation until the concentrate becomes 0.5-1 mL.
Repeat 3.5.4 and 3.5.5.
Transfer concentrated AAV to a new 1.5 mL tube and store at 4 °C or -20 °C.
		​NOTE: AAV can be used in P1 facilities but follow local rules and regulations. AAV can be produced by conventional methods as well.
Calculation of AAV titer
	
Mix 5 μL of AAV, 195 μL of DMEM-Pyr, and 10 U of benzonase and incubate at 37 °C for 1 h.
Add 200 μL of proteinase K buffer (0.02 M Tris HCl and 1% SDS) and 5 μL of proteinase K (20 mg/mL) and incubate at 37 °C for 1 h.

Carefully prepare 400 μL of a 25:24:1 Phenol/chloroform/isoamyl alcohol solution, vortex for 1 min, and centrifuge at 20,000 x g for 1 min.
Transfer 200 μL of the aqueous phase to a new 1.5 mL tube, which will yield approximately half of the original AAV genomes.
Add 1 μL of Glycogen (20 mg/mL) to 20 μL of 3 M CH3COONa (pH 5.2) and vortex. Add 250 μL of 2-Propanol to 100 μL of 100% ethanol and vortex again.
Incubate at -80 °C for 15 min. Then centrifuge at 20,000 x g for 30 min at 4 °C.
Aspirate supernatant and add 70% ethanol to the tube. Then, centrifuge at 20,000 x g, 4 °C for 5 min.
Aspirate supernatant and air dry until the pellet becomes clear.
Add 200 μL of Tris-Ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (TE; pH 8.0) to resolve the AAV genomes. Then, dilute the sample 100-fold with TE.
Prepare a standard with pAAV-CMV-Vector at 6.5 ng/μL with TE to obtain 109 vector genomes (vg)/ μL. Then, make a series of 10-fold dilution from 104 to 108 with TE.
Mix 1 μL of sample DNA (or the standards), 0.4 μL of primers (5 μM), 3.6 μL of distilled water, and 5 μL of SYBR Green master mix. Primers, located on ITR, are 5′-GGAACCCCTAGTGATGGAGTT-3′ and 5′-CGGCCTCAGTGAGCGA-3′.
Perform real-time PCR with the following condition: Initial denature at 95 °C for 60 s, 40 cycles of denaturing at 95 °C for 15 s, and annealing and extension at 60 °C for 30 s, followed by melting curve.

Based on the standards and Ct values, a real-time PCR machine provides the copy number of vector genome in 1 μL of a sample. Calculate original AAV titer using the following equation: a copy number provided by real-time PCR (vg/μL) x 8 x 103 x 2, wherein 8 x 103 as a dilution factor during AAV genome isolation, and 2 as the difference factor of AAV (single strand) and plasmid (double strand).
Transduction to PSC-CMs
	
Count PSC-CMs in an extra well or extra dish.
Dilute AAVs (1 x 104 to 1 x 106 vg/cell) to make up 50 μL with PBS. Apply AAVs at the multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 1 x 104 to 1 x 106 vg/cell to PSC-CMs and culture PSC-CMs for 3 days with AAV in the corresponding differentiation media for mouse and human PSC-CMs, then change media to culture medium without AAV.
Use PSC-CMs for live-cell imaging after 7 days or more post-transduction.
4. [Optional] AAV-based purification of PSC-CMs
Preparation of AAV
	
Prepare AAV as described in Step 3 using a shuttle vector expressing blasticidin-resistant gene under the control of cTNT promoter.
Transduction to differentiating iPS cells
	
Differentiate human iPS cells for 4 days following the protocol described in Step 2 and count the number of cells in an extra well.
After changing medium at day 4, apply AAVs at the MOI of 1 x 105 vg/cell to differentiating PSCs in RPMI+B27-Ins media.
At day 7, refresh medium with RPMI+B27+Ins and add 2.5-10 μg/mL of blasticidin.
At day 10, PSC-CMs are ready to replate.
5. Preparation of PDMS stamps
Design the device pattern of 200 μm strips along with 10-25 μm grooves in between the strips using a computer-aided design (CAD) drawing software.

Draw the pattern of devices onto a chromium photomask coated with AZP1350 using UV light of a maskless lithography tool.
Develop the pattern on the photomask in a series of positive photoresist developer (e.g., chromium etchant) and rinse with DI water.
Dehydrate a silicon wafer on a hot plate at 120 °C for 15 min.
Allow the wafer to cool to room temperature and spin-coat a negative photoresist SU-8 3010 to make a height of 10-20 μm with 1500 rpm for 30 s using a spin-coater.
Soft bake the wafer in two steps on a hot plate according to the manufacturer's protocol.
After the wafer cools to room temperature, load the wafer onto the mask aligner.
Use a mask aligner to align the mask on the wafer and expose the wafer to UV light.
Conduct the post-exposure bake to the wafer in two steps on a hot plate according to the manufacturer's protocol.
Develop the wafer in a series of SU-8 developer and 2-Propanol, then dry the wafer with a nitrogen stream.
Transfer the wafer into a Petri dish of a suitable size.
Mix PDMS elastomer and its curing agent in a ratio 10:1 w/w and pour the mixture into the Petri dish.
Degas the PDMS in a desiccator until all air bubbles disappear, then cure PDMS on hot plate at 80 °C for 2 h.
Peel the cured PDMS off from the master mold using a tweezer, then cut out the portion with the design to be a PDMS stamp.
	​NOTE: Shape can be square, however, an octagonal shape transfers the pattern better at the edge.
6. Patterned culture of pluripotent stem cell-derived cardiomyocytes
Remove dust from the surface of PDMS stamps using mending tape.

Submerge the stamps into 70% ethanol to sterilize. Then, blow ethanol off the surface of the stamps using an air duster.
Apply 5-10 μL of 0.5 wt% 2-methacryloyloxyethyl phosphorylcholine (MPC) polymer/ethanol on the surface of PDMS stamps.
	NOTE: Uneven distribution of MPC polymer may cause a disrupted pattern.
Incubate 10-30 min until MPC polymer is completely dried.
Place the stamps in contact with coverslips of a glass-bottom culture plate or a 35 mm imaging dish with a polymer coverslip and put a weight (e.g., a AAA battery) on the stamp for 10 min.
Remove the weight and stamps. Then, confirm that the pattern has been transferred under microscope.
	NOTE: Stamped plates/dishes can be stored up to 1 week at room temperature.
Wash the stamped wells/dishes with PBS two times.
Dilute LN511-E8 with PBS at 2-4 μg/mL and coat the dish with LN511-E8 at 0.5-1 μg/cm2. For human PSC-CMs, dilute LN511-E8 with 0.1% gelatin solution instead of PBS. Then, incubate for at least 1 h (optimally, more than 4 h).
Plate cells as described in previous sections.
7. Time-lapse imaging of sarcomeres under fluorescent microscope
Turn on and connect the microscope, associated computer, and also all of the required peripherals.
To perform time-lapse imaging, capture time-lapse images with the highest magnification (100X objective lens with oil emersion).
Select live-imaging conditions. To obtain good representative data, try to adjust to the highest framerate (minimum of 20 ms or 50 frames per second is recommended). Set the shutter open and apply a necessary binning (4 X 4) and a crop of the acquisition area to achieve the shortest intervals between images during the time-lapse imaging.

NOTE: The setting may vary depending on the configurations of microscopes. The camera needs to be high-sensitivity and is able to transfer the data to the connected PC fast enough. To this end, we used ORCA flash with Camera-link. We have tested a spinning confocal microscopy and have acquired images at 400 frames per second.
	
[Optional] If the beating rate of the cells is low, evoke the cells by electrical field stimulation.
Run the time-lapse record
	
Ensure that the imaged fields remain in focus during recording the time-lapse image.
Save the time-lapse images into an appropriate folder.
8. Analysis of time-lapse imaging using SarcOptiM, an ImageJ/Fiji plugin
Load a series of time-lapse images into ImageJ. For Olympus VSI format, open files through OlympusViewer Plugin.
Adjust brightness and contrast of the image to observe the sarcomere pattern clearly (Image | Adjust | Brightness/Contrast).
Open SarcOptiM by clicking More tools menu (>>) and selecting SarcOptiM.
Calibrate the program by pressing Ctrl + Shift + P and 1 μm button on the toolbar and following the instructions of the dialog boxes.
Draw a line across the region of the sarcomere that will be used to measure the sarcomere shortening.
Start sarcomere shortening analysis by pressing SingleCell (AVI) on the toolbar. Representative data is shown in Figure 1 and Figure 2.
